text: <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Suppresses HIV-1 Gene Expression in Part through Blocking Activation of NF-kappaB

If <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions as a repressor of NF-kappaB - dependent gene expression , then we hypothesized that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression could selectively down - regulate transcription from promoters previously shown to be responsive to NF-kappaB .

To address this question , we examined the transcriptional activation of the HIV-1 LTR , which contains two tandem cis - acting NF-kappaB binding sites located between positions -102 and -81 with respect to the transcription initiation site [ 21 ] .
NF-kappaB plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression directed from the HIV-1 LTR in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells [ 21 ] .

Overexpression of full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , in HEK 293T cells was able to inhibit basal activation of the HIV-1 LTR ( Figure 3A ) , similar to what was previously demonstrated with the synthetic NF-kappaB reporter vector ( Figure 2B ) .

text: Furthermore , HIV-1 LTR activation was suppressed by full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Jurkat T cells ( Figure 3B ) .

To demonstrate that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated HIV-1 LTR repression was associated with interactions with NF-kappaB bound to the HIV-1 LTR , we compared basal activation of the HIV-1 LTR or an identical HIV-1 LTR lacking the NF-kappaB sites located between -102 and -81 ( HIV-1 delta-kappaB LTR ) ( Figure 3C ) .

This mutant HIV-1 LTR construct exhibited reduced levels of transcription compared to the parental HIV-1 LTR in purified healthy donor <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( unpublished data ) .

However , directly comparing the effect of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression on the activation of these two viral promoters demonstrated that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was more capable of suppressing transcriptional activation of the HIV-1 LTR ( Figure 3D ) compared to the mutated HIV-1 LTR ( Figure 3E ) .
These results suggest that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> down-regulation of HIV-1 LTR activation was mediated at least in part by cis - acting NF-kappaB binding sites .

Residual levels of inhibition of the HIV-1 delta-kappaB LTR by <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be due to NF - AT binding sites located upstream of the NF-kappaB sites within the HIV-1 LTR [ 22 , 23 ] .
